is the process of acquiring knowledge or skill.

is an act of learning something so that you will remember it exactly.
is to identify or acknowledge something as previously been seen, known or encountered.
is to bring back to mind what has been learned or experienced.

Communicative skills.
Recall facts and basic concept. Define, duplicate, list, memorize, repeat, state.
Explain ideas or concept. Classify, describe, discuss, explain, identify, locate, recognize, report, select, translate.
Use information in new situation. Execute, implement, solve, use, demonstrate, interpret, operate, schedule, sketch.
Draw connections among ideas. Differentiate, organize, relate, compare, contrast, distinguish, examine, experiment, question.
Justify a stand or decision. Appraise, argue, defend, judge, select, support, value, critique, weigh.
Produce new or original work. Design, assemble, construct, conjecture, develop, formulate.
Stored in amygdala.
Stored in hippocampus. Parietal lobe.
Stored in putamen. Learned skills and procedures
Stored in cortex. Memories of personal and life events
Stored in temporal lobe. Learned facts and details
Memories are formed by electrical signals making connections between nerve cells so that they form a network.
A measure of memory in which the person must retrieve information learned earlier.
A measure of memory in which the person need only identify items previously learned.
Review or relearning previously learned information.
Memory from our senses. Last for a few secs.
Prefrontal cortex. Lost after around 20 secs. Limited capacity.
Often activated nerve cell network creates a long term memory. Lasts for months or several number of years.
Perceiving visual objects. Encode visual information.
Hearing sounds. Encoding audio information.
Encoding information perceive through sense of touch.
Joint and muscle sensor. Receptors in the joints detect their movement. Muscles sensors detects the stretching and contracting of muscles as well as the forces that are acting on it.
Smelling scents. Tasting flavors. Olfactory receptors detects scent. Olfactory bulb gathers scent signals and passes them to the brain. Taste buds detect the taste.
Encoding sensory input that has a particular meaning or context. Facts and details.
Combinations of encoding techniques.
Encoding information on basic level. Auditory or visual level. Based on the sound, structure or appearance of a word + low level encapsulation.
Encodes semantically based on the actual meaning of the word or combination of encoding techniques + high level encapsulation.
Memory aids. Use vivid imagery and organizational devices. Acronym, rhymes, musical, acrostics, imagery.
Organizing items into familiar manageable units.
Shopping list. Checklist.
Associate, link, connect or attribute an info from other information.
Review learned information in a specified time frame. Ex. after an hour → a day → a week → a month → 3 months.
Creative and effective note taking. Offers an overview of topic and complex information in a visual form.
Retrieve the information from the brain through practice testing, active reading, engaging in discussions and etc.
